title: compile() (not a color function)
content: SASS provides color functions. Identify functions that help manipulate colors programmatically.
explanation: SASS color functions: lighten(), darken(), saturate(), desaturate(), fade-in(), fade-out(), mix(), adjust-color(), scale-color(). Enable programmatic color manipulation, theming, variations. Very useful for design systems.

options.explanation: Correct. These adjust color brightness.
Correct. These adjust color intensity.
Correct. mix() blends two colors.
Incorrect. This is not a color manipulation function.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: Prevents animations from running
content: Performance optimization for animations. Explain will-change and best practices for usage.
explanation: will-change hints browser about upcoming changes, enables optimization (GPU layer promotion). Use sparingly: only when animation is about to start, remove after. Overuse causes memory issues. Better to use only when needed, not preemptively.

options.text: Hints browser about upcoming changes for optimization; use sparingly, remove after animation
options.explanation: Correct. will-change should be used carefully.

options.text: Should be applied to all animated elements
options.explanation: Incorrect. Overuse causes performance issues.
Incorrect. Most animations work fine without it.
Incorrect. will-change optimizes animations.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: backwards only works with JavaScript
content: Animation fill modes control element state before/after animation. Explain the different fill modes.
explanation: none: no styles before/after. forwards: keeps final keyframe styles after animation. backwards: applies first keyframe styles before delay. both: forwards + backwards. Useful for maintaining animation end state or starting state during delay.

options.text: forwards: keep final styles; backwards: apply first styles during delay; both: combine both
options.explanation: Correct. fill-mode controls pre/post animation styles.
Incorrect. They control different aspects.
Incorrect. forwards maintains end state.
Incorrect. fill-mode is pure CSS.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: transform only works with JavaScript
content: Positioning animations can be done multiple ways. Explain why transform is preferred over position properties.
explanation: transform: translate() uses GPU, doesn't trigger layout, smoother. left/top: triggers layout recalculation, repaint, slower. Transform is composited on GPU layer. Position properties cause reflow. Always prefer transform for animations.

options.text: transform: GPU-accelerated, no layout; left/top: triggers layout, slower
options.explanation: Correct. transform is much more performant.
Incorrect. transform is significantly faster.
Incorrect. transform is preferred for animations.
Incorrect. CSS transform is pure CSS.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: All properties have equal performance
content: Animation performance matters for smooth UX. Identify properties that impact animation performance.
explanation: Properties: transform and opacity are GPU-accelerated (best). width, height, margin, padding trigger layout (slow). background-color triggers paint (medium). Use transform/opacity when possible. Avoid animating layout-triggering properties.

options.explanation: Correct. transform is highly performant.
Correct. opacity is highly performant.
Correct. Layout-triggering properties are slower.
Incorrect. Performance varies significantly.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: All properties should always be animated separately
content: Grouping animated properties affects performance. Identify best practices for property grouping.
explanation: Group GPU-accelerated properties (transform, opacity) together. Avoid mixing layout properties (width, margin) with transform. Animate transform properties together (translate, rotate, scale). Keep animations on same composite layer.

options.explanation: Correct. Transform properties work well together.
Correct. Both are performant together.

options.text: width with transform (mixing layout and composite)
options.explanation: Incorrect. Mixing layout and composite hurts performance.

options.text: All properties should always be animated separately
options.explanation: Incorrect. Grouping compatible properties is better.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: Only works with JavaScript
content: Timing functions control animation speed curves. Explain different timing functions and their effects.
explanation: Timing function controls speed curve: ease (slow-fast-slow, default), linear (constant speed), ease-in (slow start), ease-out (slow end), ease-in-out (slow both ends), cubic-bezier() (custom curve). Creates natural-feeling motion.

options.text: Controls animation speed curve; ease: slow-fast-slow; linear: constant; cubic-bezier: custom
options.explanation: Correct. Timing functions create motion curves.
Incorrect. They create different motion feels.
Incorrect. animation-duration controls duration.
Incorrect. Timing functions are pure CSS.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: Only works with JavaScript
content: Transform origin controls the point around which transformations occur. Explain its purpose and usage.
explanation: transform-origin sets the point for transform operations (rotate, scale, skew). Default: center (50% 50%). Can be keywords (top, left, center) or coordinates. Affects where element rotates/scales from. Essential for natural-looking animations.

options.text: Sets the point for transform operations (rotate/scale); default is center
options.explanation: Correct. transform-origin controls transformation point.
Incorrect. It controls transformation point, not speed.
Incorrect. transform-origin is a standard property.
Incorrect. transform-origin is pure CSS.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: Only works on mobile devices
content: Accessibility requires respecting user motion preferences. Explain prefers-reduced-motion and implementation.
explanation: prefers-reduced-motion: user prefers less animation (accessibility setting). Should disable or reduce animations. Use <cod@media (prefers-reduced-motion: reduce) to disable animations. Essential for accessibility, prevents motion sickness, respects user choice.

options.text: Detects user preference for reduced motion; should disable/reduce animations for accessibility
options.explanation: Correct. Essential for accessibility.
Incorrect. It detects preference to reduce motion.
Incorrect. It's important for accessibility.
Incorrect. Works on all devices with the setting.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: animation only works with JavaScript
content: CSS provides two animation mechanisms. Explain transitions vs animations and their use cases.
explanation: transition: simple state changes (hover, focus), single property changes, triggered by state. animation: complex multi-step animations, keyframe-based, can loop/reverse, more control. Use transition for simple changes, animation for complex sequences.

options.text: transition: simple state changes; animation: complex keyframe sequences
options.explanation: Correct. Transitions are simpler, animations more powerful.
Incorrect. They serve different purposes.
Incorrect. Both are valid and useful.
Incorrect. CSS animations are pure CSS.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: color (animatable)
content: Not all CSS properties are animatable. Identify which properties can be animated smoothly.
explanation: Animatable: transform, opacity, color, background-color, width, height, margin, padding, border-radius, etc. Non-animatable: display, position (static/relative/absolute), font-family, z-index (discrete). Transform and opacity are most performant (GPU-accelerated).

options.explanation: Correct. transform is highly performant.
Correct. opacity is highly performant.
Incorrect. display cannot be animated.
Correct. color can be animated.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: px (absolute, less flexible)
content: Unit choice affects responsiveness. Identify units that work well for responsive layouts.
explanation: Relative units are best: rem (root-relative), em (parent-relative), % (container-relative), vw/vh (viewport-relative), vmin/vmax (viewport min/max). Absolute units (px) are less flexible but sometimes needed for precise control.

options.explanation: Correct. rem is excellent for responsive design.
Correct. Viewport units enable viewport-based sizing.
Correct. Percentages are flexible and responsive.
Incorrect. px is absolute and less flexible for responsive design.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: Requires JavaScript
content: Responsive media requires proper sizing. Explain object-fit and its values for controlling media display.
explanation: object-fit controls how replaced content (img, video) fits container: fill (stretch), contain (fit entire, may have gaps), cover (fill, may crop), none (original size), scale-down (smaller of contain/none). Essential for responsive images in fixed containers.

options.text: Controls how img/video fits container: fill, contain, cover, none, scale-down
options.explanation: Correct. object-fit provides multiple fitting options.
Incorrect. object-fit works with img and video elements.
Incorrect. object-fit is a standard CSS property.
Incorrect. object-fit is pure CSS.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: height=device-height (usually not needed)
content: Viewport configuration is crucial for mobile responsiveness. Identify essential viewport settings.
explanation: width=device-width (sets viewport width), initial-scale=1 (prevents zoom on load), user-scalable (controls zoom). maximum-scale can prevent accessibility. Essential: width=device-width, initial-scale=1.

options.explanation: Correct. Essential for responsive design.
Correct. Prevents unwanted zoom on load.
Incorrect. Disabling zoom harms accessibility.
Incorrect. Height is rarely needed for viewport.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: min() always returns the maximum
content: CSS comparison functions enable flexible sizing. Explain min(), max(), and clamp() and their use cases.
explanation: min(a, b): returns smaller value. max(a, b): returns larger value. clamp(min, val, max): constrains value between min and max. Use min() for maximum limits, max() for minimum limits, clamp() for both (most common for responsive sizing).

options.text: min(): smaller value; max(): larger value; clamp(): value between min and max
options.explanation: Correct. Each function serves different comparison purposes.
Incorrect. They perform different comparisons.
Incorrect. clamp() is a modern, useful function.
Incorrect. min() returns the minimum value.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: Only works with pixels
content: Fluid typography requires flexible sizing. Explain clamp() and how it creates responsive text sizes.
explanation: clamp(min, preferred, max) sets value between min and max, with preferred scaling. Enables fluid typography that scales with viewport. Preferred value typically uses vw units. Example: clamp(1rem, 4vw, 2rem) scales between <cod1rem and <cod2rem based on viewport.

options.text: Sets value between min and max with fluid scaling; enables responsive typography
options.explanation: Correct. clamp() enables fluid responsive sizing.
Incorrect. clamp() is for fluid sizing.

options.text: Is deprecated in favor of media queries
options.explanation: Incorrect. clamp() is a modern feature that complements media queries.
Incorrect. clamp() works with any CSS unit.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: min-width only works on mobile
content: Media query direction matters for responsive design. Explain min-width vs max-width and their use cases.
explanation: min-width: applies styles when viewport is at least X wide (mobile-first). max-width: applies when viewport is at most X wide (desktop-first). Use min-width for mobile-first, max-width for desktop-first. Mobile-first (min-width) is preferred.

options.text: min-width: mobile-first (viewport >= X); max-width: desktop-first (viewport <= X)
options.explanation: Correct. min-width is for mobile-first approach.
Incorrect. They work in opposite directions.
Incorrect. min-width (mobile-first) is generally preferred.
Incorrect. min-width works on all devices.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: Mobile-first only works on mobile devices
content: Responsive design strategies differ. Explain mobile-first approach and why it's preferred over desktop-first.
explanation: Mobile-first: start with mobile styles, add larger screen styles with min-width media queries. Desktop-first: start with desktop, override with max-width. Mobile-first advantages: progressive enhancement, smaller initial CSS, better performance, aligns with mobile usage.

options.text: Mobile-first: start mobile, enhance for larger screens; better performance and progressive enhancement
options.explanation: Correct. Mobile-first is the modern best practice.
Incorrect. Mobile-first is generally preferred.
Incorrect. Mobile-first typically has better performance.

options.text: Mobile-first only works on mobile devices
options.explanation: Incorrect. Mobile-first works on all devices.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: Media queries are always better
content: Container queries are a modern CSS feature. Explain their purpose and advantages over media queries.
explanation: Media queries: based on viewport size. Container queries: based on container size. Container queries enable component-level responsiveness (not just page-level). More flexible, better for component libraries. Limited browser support (Chrome 105+, Safari 16+).

options.text: Media queries: viewport-based; Container queries: container-based (component-level responsiveness)
options.explanation: Correct. Container queries enable component-level responsiveness.
Incorrect. They query different things.
Incorrect. Container queries are a modern feature.
Incorrect. Container queries solve different problems.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: Requires JavaScript
content: Maintaining aspect ratios is important for responsive design. Explain the aspect-ratio property and its benefits.
explanation: aspect-ratio maintains width<cod:height ratio when one dimension changes. Prevents layout shift, maintains design integrity. Useful for images, videos, cards. Format: aspect-ratio: 16/9 or aspect-ratio: 1 (square). Works with width or height.

options.text: Maintains width<cod:height ratio; prevents layout shift in responsive designs
options.explanation: Correct. aspect-ratio prevents layout shift.
Incorrect. aspect-ratio works with any element.
Incorrect. aspect-ratio is a modern CSS feature.
Incorrect. aspect-ratio is pure CSS.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: device-type (not a real feature)
content: Media queries can target specific device characteristics. Identify features that enable precise targeting.
explanation: width/height: viewport size. orientation: portrait/landscape. resolution: pixel density. prefers-color-scheme: dark/light mode. prefers-reduced-motion: accessibility. hover: pointer capability. pointer: fine/coarse/none.

options.explanation: Correct. orientation targets device orientation.
Correct. Targets user's color scheme preference.
Correct. Detects if device supports hover.
Incorrect. This is not a valid media query feature.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: Both work on the same axis
content: Flexbox alignment is crucial for layouts. Explain when to use justify-content vs align-items and their different axes.
explanation: justify-content aligns items along main axis (row: horizontal, column: vertical). align-items aligns items along cross axis (row: vertical, column: horizontal). Use justify-content for main axis spacing, align-items for cross-axis alignment.

options.text: justify-content: main axis; align-items: cross axis
options.explanation: Correct. They work on different axes.
Incorrect. They work on different axes.

options.text: justify-content: cross axis; align-items: main axis
options.explanation: Incorrect. It's the opposite.

options.text: Both work on the same axis
options.explanation: Incorrect. They work on perpendicular axes.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: fixed sticks within container
content: Sticky positioning is useful for headers and navigation. Explain how it works and when to use it vs fixed.
explanation: sticky: element sticks when scrolling reaches threshold (within container). fixed: always positioned relative to viewport. sticky stays in flow until threshold, then sticks. fixed is always removed from flow. Use sticky for headers in scrollable content, fixed for always-visible nav.

options.text: sticky: sticks within container when scrolling; fixed: always relative to viewport
options.explanation: Correct. sticky is container-relative, fixed is viewport-relative.
Incorrect. They behave differently.

options.text: sticky is always removed from flow
options.explanation: Incorrect. sticky starts in flow, then sticks.
Incorrect. fixed is always viewport-relative.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: fr only works with fixed widths
content: Grid fractional units are powerful for responsive layouts. Explain how ''fr'' units work and when to use them.
explanation: 'fr' (fraction) distributes available space proportionally. <cod1fr <cod2fr means second column gets twice the space. Percentages are fixed relative to container. 'fr' is more flexible for responsive grids. Use 'fr' for flexible columns, % for fixed proportions.

options.text: fr distributes available space proportionally; % is fixed relative to container
options.explanation: Correct. fr is more flexible for grid layouts.
Incorrect. fr is more flexible than percentages.
Incorrect. fr is often better for flexible grid layouts.

options.text: fr only works with fixed widths
options.explanation: Incorrect. fr works with flexible/available space.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: flex-shrink prevents items from growing
content: Flexbox sizing requires understanding these properties. Explain how they work together to control flex item sizes.
explanation: flex-basis: initial size before growing/shrinking. flex-grow: how much item grows relative to others (0 = no grow). flex-shrink: how much item shrinks relative to others (0 = no shrink). flex: shorthand for grow shrink basis.

options.text: flex-basis: initial size; flex-grow: growth factor; flex-shrink: shrink factor
options.explanation: Correct. This describes their roles.
Incorrect. They control different aspects of sizing.
Incorrect. flex-basis controls initial size.
Incorrect. flex-shrink controls shrinking, not growing.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: align-self sets alignment for all items
content: Flexbox provides both container and item-level alignment. Explain align-self vs align-items.
explanation: align-items sets alignment for all flex items (container property). align-self overrides align-items for individual items (item property). Use align-items for uniform alignment, align-self for exceptions.

options.text: align-items: all items; align-self: individual item override
options.explanation: Correct. align-self overrides align-items for specific items.
Incorrect. One is container-level, one is item-level.
Incorrect. Both are valid and serve different purposes.

options.text: align-self sets alignment for all items
options.explanation: Incorrect. align-self is for individual items.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: static (default, in flow)
content: Understanding positioning and flow is crucial. Identify which position values remove elements from normal flow.
explanation: absolute and fixed remove from flow. relative and sticky stay in flow (sticky can overlap but starts in flow). static is default (in flow). Elements removed from flow don't affect sibling positioning.

options.explanation: Correct. absolute removes from flow.

options.text: fixed (removed from flow, relative to viewport)
options.explanation: Correct. fixed removes from flow.
Incorrect. relative stays in normal flow.
Incorrect. static is in normal flow.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: grid-gap (spacing between items)
content: CSS Grid provides powerful layout control. Identify properties that control where items are placed in the grid.
explanation: grid-column, grid-row, grid-area, and grid-template-areas control item placement. grid-gap controls spacing. grid-template-columns/rows define the grid structure.

options.explanation: Correct. grid-column controls column placement.
Correct. grid-row controls row placement.
Correct. grid-area places items in named areas.
Incorrect. grid-gap controls spacing, not placement.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: Only works with fixed grid sizes
content: Subgrid is a modern CSS Grid feature. Explain its purpose and use cases for nested grid layouts.
explanation: subgrid allows nested grid to inherit parent grid tracks. Solves alignment issues in nested grids. Without subgrid, nested grids are independent. With subgrid, child grid aligns with parent tracks. Limited browser support (Firefox, Safari).

options.text: Allows nested grid to inherit parent grid tracks for alignment
options.explanation: Correct. subgrid solves nested grid alignment.

options.text: Creates a smaller grid within a larger grid
options.explanation: Incorrect. That's just a nested grid, not subgrid.

options.text: Is deprecated in favor of Flexbox
options.explanation: Incorrect. subgrid is a modern feature.

options.text: Only works with fixed grid sizes
options.explanation: Incorrect. subgrid works with flexible grids.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: flex-basis (affects when items wrap)
content: Flexbox wrapping controls multi-line layouts. Identify properties that affect how flex items wrap.
explanation: flex-wrap controls wrapping (nowrap, wrap, wrap-reverse). flex-direction affects wrap direction. align-content aligns wrapped lines. flex-basis affects when items wrap (if too large).

options.explanation: Correct. flex-wrap directly controls wrapping.
Correct. align-content affects wrapped content.
Incorrect. justify-content doesn't control wrapping.
Correct. Item size affects wrapping.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: grid-template-columns/rows is only for 1D layouts
content: CSS Grid provides multiple ways to define layouts. Explain when to use named areas vs explicit tracks.
explanation: grid-template-areas: visual/declarative layout with named areas (easier to read, maintain). grid-template-columns/rows: explicit track sizing (more control, less readable). Can combine both. Areas are better for semantic layouts, explicit tracks for precise control.

options.text: grid-template-areas: visual named layout; grid-template-columns/rows: explicit track sizing
options.explanation: Correct. Areas are more visual, explicit tracks more precise.
Incorrect. They define grids differently.
Incorrect. Both are valid approaches.
Incorrect. Both work for 2D grid layouts.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: rem
content: Understanding unit types is important. Identify which CSS units are absolute (fixed size) vs relative.
explanation: Absolute units: px (pixels), pt (points), pc (picas), in (inches), cm (centimeters), mm (millimeters). Relative units: em, rem, %, vw, vh, vmin, vmax, ch, ex. Absolute units don't scale with user preferences.

options.explanation: Correct. px is an absolute unit.
Correct. pt is an absolute unit.
Incorrect. em is a relative unit.
Incorrect. rem is a relative unit.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: Element selectors (div)
content: Understanding selector specificity helps resolve style conflicts. Identify the highest specificity selectors.
explanation: Inline styles (style='...') have highest specificity (1000). IDs (<cod#id) have 100. Classes (<cod.class), attributes (<cod[attr]), and pseudo-classes (<cod:hover) have 10. Elements (div) and pseudo-elements (<cod::before) have 1.

options.explanation: Correct. Inline styles have highest specificity.
Correct. IDs have high specificity (100).
Incorrect. Classes have lower specificity (10) than IDs.
Incorrect. Elements have lowest specificity (1).

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: border-box excludes padding from width
content: Box model understanding is fundamental. Explain how box-sizing affects width and height calculations.
explanation: content-box: width/height = content only (padding/border add to total). border-box: width/height = content + padding + border (total size matches specified). border-box is more intuitive and commonly used in modern CSS.

options.text: content-box: width excludes padding/border; border-box: width includes padding/border
options.explanation: Correct. This is how box-sizing works.
Incorrect. They calculate width differently.
Incorrect. Both are valid, just different behaviors.
Incorrect. border-box includes padding and border in width.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: em is for fonts, rem is for spacing
content: Relative units are important for responsive design. Explain when to use em vs rem and their calculation differences.
explanation: 'em' is relative to parent element's font-size (compounds with nesting). 'rem' is relative to root element's font-size (consistent regardless of nesting). Use 'rem' for predictable sizing, 'em' for component-relative sizing.

options.text: em is relative to parent; rem is relative to root element
options.explanation: Correct. This is the key difference.

options.text: em is relative to root; rem is relative to parent
options.explanation: Incorrect. It's the opposite.
Incorrect. They calculate differently.

options.text: em is for fonts, rem is for spacing
options.explanation: Incorrect. Both can be used for any property.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: Both remove elements from flow
content: Positioning is crucial for layout. Explain how relative and absolute positioning differ in behavior and use cases.
explanation: relative: element stays in normal flow, offset from its original position. absolute: element removed from flow, positioned relative to nearest positioned ancestor (or viewport). relative doesn't affect siblings, absolute does. Use relative for offsetting, absolute for overlays/tooltips.

options.text: relative: stays in flow with offset; absolute: removed from flow, positioned relative to ancestor
options.explanation: Correct. This describes their behavior.
Incorrect. They behave very differently.

options.text: absolute stays in flow, relative is removed
options.explanation: Incorrect. It's the opposite.
Incorrect. Only absolute removes from flow.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: Randomly selects from conflicting styles
content: The cascade is fundamental to CSS. Explain how the cascade resolves conflicts between multiple style rules.
explanation: Cascade order: 1) Importance (!important), 2) Specificity (higher wins), 3) Source order (later wins if equal). Stylesheet order matters when specificity is equal. User agent styles < author styles < user styles (with !important).

options.text: Resolves conflicts by: Importance > Specificity > Source order
options.explanation: Correct. This is the cascade order.

options.text: Always uses the last declared style
options.explanation: Incorrect. Specificity and importance matter first.

options.text: Always uses the most specific selector
options.explanation: Incorrect. !important can override specificity.
Incorrect. Cascade follows specific rules.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: display: none keeps the space
content: Hiding elements has different methods. Explain the layout and rendering differences between these properties.
explanation: display: none removes element from layout flow (takes no space, not accessible). visibility: hidden keeps element in layout (takes space, not visible, not accessible). opacity: 0 keeps element visible to screen readers but invisible.

options.text: display: none removes from layout; visibility: hidden keeps space but hides element
options.explanation: Correct. This is the key difference.
Incorrect. They affect layout differently.
Incorrect. visibility: hidden keeps the space.
Incorrect. display: none removes the element from layout.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: Only works with inline styles
content: The !important flag overrides specificity. Explain its purpose and best practices for usage.
explanation: !important overrides all other declarations regardless of specificity. Should be used sparingly: for utility classes, framework overrides, or critical styles. Overuse makes CSS hard to maintain and debug. Consider refactoring instead.

options.text: Overrides all other declarations; use sparingly for critical styles or utility classes
options.explanation: Correct. !important is powerful but should be used carefully.
Incorrect. !important doesn't change specificity, it overrides it.

options.text: Should be used on all declarations for consistency
options.explanation: Incorrect. Overuse of !important is an anti-pattern.
Incorrect. !important works with any CSS declaration.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: line-height
content: Understanding inheritance is crucial for CSS. Identify which properties are inherited by child elements.
explanation: Inherited properties include: color, font-family, font-size, line-height, text-align, visibility, and most text-related properties. Non-inherited: margin, padding, border, width, height, background, display, position.

options.explanation: Correct. color is inherited.
Correct. font-family is inherited.
Incorrect. margin is not inherited.
Correct. line-height is inherited.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: All selectors have equal specificity
content: Senior developers must understand CSS specificity rules. Arrange the following in order from highest to lowest specificity.
explanation: Specificity order: inline styles (1000) IDs (100) classes/attributes/pseudo-classes (10) elements/pseudo-elements (1). !important overrides all but is not part of specificity calculation. More specific selectors win.

options.explanation: Correct. This is the specificity hierarchy.
Incorrect. Inline styles have the highest specificity.
Incorrect. IDs have higher specificity than classes.
Incorrect. Different selector types have different specificity values.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: What are the features of create react app?
content: What are the features of create react app?
explanation:
Below are the list of some of the features provided by create react app.

    1.  React, JSX, ES6, Typescript and Flow syntax support.
    2.  Autoprefixed CSS
    3.  CSS Reset/Normalize
    4.  A live development server
    5.  A fast interactive unit test runner with built-in support for coverage reporting
    6.  A build script to bundle JS, CSS, and images for production, with hashes and sourcemaps
    7.  An offline-first service worker and a web app manifest, meeting all the Progressive Web App criteria.

resources.title: React - The Complete Guide
resources.author: Maximilian Schwarzmller
resources.description: Master React and Redux with hands-on projects

title: What is state mutation and how to prevent it?
explanation:
`State mutation` happens when you try to update the state of a component without actually using `setState` function. This can happen when you are trying to do some computations using a state variable and unknowingly save the result in the same state variable. This is the main reason why it is advised to return new instances of state variables from the reducers by using Object.assign({}, ...) or spread syntax.

    This can cause unknown issues in the UI as the value of the state variable got updated without telling React to check what all components were being affected from this update and it can cause UI bugs.

    Ex:


    **How to prevent it:** Make sure your state variables are immutable by either enforcing immutability by using plugins like Immutable.js, always using `setState` to make updates, and returning new instances in reducers when sending updated state values.

resources.title: React - The Complete Guide
resources.author: Maximilian Schwarzmller
resources.description: Master React and Redux with hands-on projects

title: How do you create HOC using render props?
explanation:
You can implement most higher-order components (HOC) using a regular component with a render prop. For example, if you would prefer to have a withMouse HOC instead of a <Mous component, you could easily create one using a regular <Mous with a render prop.


    This way render props gives the flexibility of using either pattern.

resources.title: React - The Complete Guide
resources.author: Maximilian Schwarzmller
resources.description: Master React and Redux with hands-on projects

title: What is react scripts?
content: What is react scripts?
explanation: The `react-scripts` package is a set of scripts from the create-react-app starter pack which helps you kick off projects without configuring. The `react-scripts start` command sets up the development environment and starts a server, as well as hot module reloading.

resources.title: Create React App Tutorial
resources.author: The Net Ninja
resources.description: Complete guide to create-react-app and react-scripts

title: What is the purpose of renderToNodeStream method?
content: What is the purpose of renderToNodeStream method?
explanation:
The `ReactDOMServer#renderToNodeStream` method is used to generate HTML on the server and send the markup down on the initial request for faster page loads. It also helps search engines to crawl your pages easily for SEO purposes.
    **Note:** Remember this method is not available in the browser but only server.

resources.title: React - The Complete Guide
resources.author: Maximilian Schwarzmller
resources.description: Master React and Redux with hands-on projects

title: How do you get redux scaffolding using create-react-app?
content:
How do you get redux scaffolding using create-react-app?

```javascript
    npx create-react-app my-app --template redux-typescript
```
explanation:
Redux team has provided official redux+js or redux+typescript templates for create-react-app project. The generated project setup includes,
    1.  Redux Toolkit and React-Redux dependencies
    2.  Create and configure Redux store
    3.  React-Redux `<Provider` passing the store to React components
    4.  Small "counter" example to demo how to add redux logic and React-Redux hooks API to interact with the store from components
        The below commands need to be executed along with template option as below,
    5.  **Javascript template:**
    2.  **Typescript template:**

resources.title: React - The Complete Guide
resources.author: Maximilian Schwarzmller
resources.description: Master React and Redux with hands-on projects

title: Why do you need additional care for component libraries while using forward refs?
content: Why do you need additional care for component libraries while using forward refs?
explanation: When you start using forwardRef in a component library, you should treat it as a breaking change and release a new major version of your library. This is because your library likely has a different behavior such as what refs get assigned to, and what types are exported. These changes can break apps and other libraries that depend on the old behavior.

title: How to prevent component from rendering?
explanation:
You can prevent component from rendering by returning null based on specific condition. This way it can conditionally render component.



    In the above example, the `greeting` component skips its rendering section by applying condition and returning null value.

resources.author: Maximilian Schwarzmller
resources.description: Master React and Redux with hands-on projects

title: Is ref argument available for all functions or class components?
content: Is ref argument available for all functions or class components?
explanation: Regular function or class components don't receive the ref argument, and ref is not available in props either. The second ref argument only exists when you define a component with React.forwardRef call.
